title: U.S. Olympic Uniforms Come With Responsibility
sub_head: As soon as athletes put them on, they act as representatives of our team.
body:
Regarding the letters from readers on protests by Olympic athletes (July 26 and 31): I have yet to read the main reason why these protests are inappropriate. It is found in one word: uniform. All these protests are made by people in uniforms.
When one wears the uniform of an organization, whether it be the U.S. military, a police department or an athletic squad, one acts as a representative of a team. As such, the team comes before the members’ desires relative to anything controversial. All team members wear standard attire and are expected to perform in a uniform manner—by the rules of behavior established by team leaders. The military and police have rules of engagement. Athletic teams must follow the rules of the game.
Team members should be expected to behave in a manner that does not bring shame or embarrassment to the team as an organization or to fellow members. The bottom line: Professional sports-team owners, and, in this latest case, the leadership of the U.S. Olympic team, have failed in their leadership duties by condoning disrespectful behavior.
Col. Ken Faulhaber, USAF (Ret.)
Ocala, Fla.
